section.title: Actuarial Notation 3 -- \ddot{a}_{\angln} and \ddot{s}_{\angln}
section.p: The actuarial symbol for the present value of an annuity due is \ddot{a}_{\angln} and for the accumulated value the symbol is \ddot{s}_{\angln} As before, for a perpetuity, n = \infty, and if the payments are K instead of 1, we multiply.

The problems from are repeated below with timelines generated by the author. Your task is to decide where to value the cash flows and write one or more equations to solve the problem, using actuarial notation as appropriate. We are not going to solve these problems until the next activity.

statement.p: Chuck needs to purchase an item in 10 years. The item costs 200 today, but its price inflates 4% per year. To finance the purchase, Chuck deposits 20 into an account at the beginning of each year for 6 years. He deposits an additional X at the beginning of years 4, 5, and 6 to meet his goal. The effective annual interest rate is 10%. Write equations, using actuarial notation, to calculate X.

figure.caption: Timeline for an item with present value 200, 4% inflation, in an annuity with 10% interest and payments of 20 or 20+X for the first 6 years.

statement.p: Bob wants to purchase a perpetuity paying 1000 per year with the first payment due at the end of year 11. He can purchase it by either:

li.p: paying 900 per year at the end of each year for 10 years; or
paying K per year at the end of each year for the first 5 years and nothing for the next 5 years.

statement.p: Write equations, using actuarial notation, to calculate K.

figure.caption: Timeline for a perpetuity paying 1000 per year with the first payment at the end of year 11.

statement.p: A perpetuity-immediate pays X per year. Brian receives the first n payments, Colleen receives the next n payments, and a charity receives the remaining payments. The share of the present value of the original perpetuity that Brian will get is 40%, and the share the charity will get is K.

figure.caption: Timeline for a perpetuity paying X per year.

statement.p: Kathryn deposits 100 into an account at the beginning of each 4-year period for 40 years. The account credits interest at an annual effective interest rate of \iota. The accumulated amount in the account at the end of 40 years is X, which is 5 times the accumulated amount in the account at the end of 20 years. Calculate X.

figure.caption: Timeline for a annuity where 100 is deposited at the beginning of each 4 year period.
